## Władysław Reymont and the 1924 Nobel Prize

The Nobel Prize in Literature 1924 was awarded to Władysław Stanisław Reymont "for his great national epic, The Peasants". Władysław Stanisław Reymont (1867–1925) was a Polish novelist and the laureate of the 1924 Nobel Prize in Literature. His best-known work is the award-winning four-volume novel Chłopi (The Peasants).

## About "Chłopi" (The Peasants)

The novel is best known as Chłopi ("The Peasants", 1904–1909), a novel in four volumes that chronicles peasant life in Poland during the four seasons of the year, for which he specifically was awarded the Nobel prize. The composition is based on the four seasons: autumn, winter, spring, and summer, which connect human life and nature.

Rather than being a naturalistic novel, Chłopi has taken on epic proportions – certainly naturalistic in method but epic in scope. The novel has been described as a Polish national epic. The novel is influenced by naturalism and is characterised by detailed environmental descriptions and a bustling cast of characters drawn from the broad masses.

## International Recognition and Translations

In 1924, when The Peasants was translated into English, Reymont finally gained international fame when his epic work received the Nobel prize in literature. Reymont received the Nobel Prize for his novel 'The Peasants' in 1924, and the book went on to be translated into many European languages.

The novel has been translated into multiple languages, including:
- English translations by Michael Henry Dziewicki (1924–1925) and Anna Zaranko (2022)
- The Library's holdings of books published before Reymont's death in 1935 are all translations – into English, into German, and even into Spanish

## Universal Themes and World Literature Reception

Its theme was universal; the novel's French translator called it a 'testimony to European peasants'. This universality helped establish the work's significance in world literature beyond its Polish origins.

Reymont was recognised "for his great national epic, The peasants". He is one of nine laureates, so far, for whom the Academy has "singled out a specific work for particular recognition", highlighting the particular literary merit of this novel.

## Literary Impact and Context

He was the second Polish recipient of the literature prize after Henryk Sienkiewicz. Reymont has acknowledged that the idea of his book was evoked by La Terre, not through his admiration of it, but through the indignation and opposition it provoked, showing how the work engaged with broader European literary traditions while presenting an authentic Polish perspective.

The novel's recognition as a "great national epic" that achieved international acclaim demonstrates its successful transition from national literature to world literature, with translations making it accessible to global audiences and critics recognizing its universal themes about peasant life and the relationship between humanity and nature.
